newsitem.title: ZIMBABWE: Britain's Prince Andrew to see Africa army drills.
newsitem.headline: Britain's Prince Andrew to see Africa army drills.

text.p: Britain's Prince Andrew arrived in Zimbabwe on Tuesday for a three-day official visit during which he will witness a landmark joint military exercise by eight southern African nations.

The prince was met at Harare airport by Zimbabwean Foreign Minister Stan Mudenge, and is to meet President Robert Mugabe on Wednesday before travelling to the southern African state's eastern Nyanga district where the 20-day military exercise is being staged.
Britain is partly funding the exercise which ends on April 20.

Some 1,100 troops from Lesotho, Malawi, Mozambique, Namibia, South Africa, Swaziland, Tanzania and Zimbabwe -- all Commonwealth members -- are taking part in the exercise, the first of its kind in Africa aimed at honing peacekeeping skills.

London's Zimbabwe-based British Military Advisory and Training Team is helping run the exercise, code-named Blue Hungwe (Fish Eagle), which it says shows its "commitment to the development of regional peacekeeping operations in Africa".
President Mugabe will also witness the exercise on Thursday, which is based on United Nations tactics and techniques of international peacekeeping.
